text: The world is filled with people waiting to be transformed. Maybe they’re waiting for you. Go out, and show them what you’ve become.
My friends
column4: there are no words for how grateful I am to have known you...

text: I leave this college for a world that I am already and have always been a part of.
We see people show their work, their truest selves shining through, and then we realize that we might never see them again.
But none of this academic and artistic work would have existed without the existential, psychological and emotional work I did
... and to which I owe a huge debt of gratitude to both my teachers and my friends.
I’m finally at a point where I love myself enough to say that I’ve done a lot of great work at Bennington
column4: which I am incredibly proud of...

text: I didn’t know, until [faculty member Kitty Brazelton] made me do it, how much I’d wanted to write a song.
This engagement produces outbursts of joy and despair in equal measure, and beauty that leaves me breathless, just when I need it most.
The work I’ve seen here is that of people who are deeply engaged with the frightening, uncomfortable aspects of themselves and the world.
...and maybe even a little disappointed about that."
Like any of life’s great anticlimaxes, graduation is an event where you wake up the morning after feeling mostly the same...
.@MarikoSilver quotes Kieran Najita on learning to work through the process
